title: Luke Chapter 20 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Luke chapter 20 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Luke Chapter 20 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Luke Chapter 20.

questions.question: Who came to Jesus while he was teaching in the temple according to Luke 20:1?
options: Chief priests and scribes with elders
The disciples only
The Pharisees alone
The Sadducees and Pharisees
questions.correctAnswer: Chief priests and scribes with elders
questions.explanation: Luke 20:1 states that the chief priests and the scribes came upon Jesus with the elders while he taught in the temple.

questions.question: What question did the chief priests and scribes ask Jesus in Luke 20:2?
options: By what authority doest thou these things?
Who is the Messiah?
Where do you come from?
When will the kingdom come?
questions.correctAnswer: By what authority doest thou these things?
questions.explanation: In Luke 20:2, they asked Jesus, 'By what authority doest thou these things? or who is he that gave thee this authority?'

questions.question: What question did Jesus ask the chief priests and scribes about John's baptism in Luke 20:4?
options: Was John's baptism from heaven or of men?
Was John a prophet or a king?
Did John teach righteousness or sin?
Was John a disciple of Moses or Elijah?
questions.correctAnswer: Was John's baptism from heaven or of men?
questions.explanation: Jesus asked them if John's baptism was from heaven or from men as recorded in Luke 20:4.

questions.question: How did the chief priests and scribes respond to Jesus' question about John's baptism in Luke 20:7?
options: They said they could not tell whence it was.
They said it was from heaven.
They said it was from men.
They refused to answer.
questions.correctAnswer: They said they could not tell whence it was.
questions.explanation: Luke 20:7 states that they answered Jesus, saying they could not tell where John's baptism came from.

questions.question: In the parable Jesus told in Luke 20:9, what did the certain man plant?
options: A vineyard
A field of wheat
An olive grove
A garden of herbs
questions.correctAnswer: A vineyard
questions.explanation: Luke 20:9 says that a certain man planted a vineyard and let it forth to husbandmen.

questions.question: What did the husbandmen do to the first servant sent to collect fruit in Luke 20:10?
options: Beat him and sent him away empty
Received him kindly and gave fruit
Ignored him
Captured him
questions.correctAnswer: Beat him and sent him away empty
questions.explanation: In Luke 20:10, the husbandmen beat the servant and sent him away without fruit.

questions.question: Who did the lord of the vineyard decide to send after the servants in Luke 20:13?
options: His beloved son
A group of soldiers
Another servant
A messenger from the king
questions.correctAnswer: His beloved son
questions.explanation: Luke 20:13 states the lord of the vineyard decided to send his beloved son hoping the husbandmen would reverence him.

questions.question: What did the husbandmen do to the son of the lord of the vineyard in Luke 20:15?
options: They killed him
They welcomed him
They ignored him
They sent him back
questions.correctAnswer: They killed him
questions.explanation: Luke 20:15 says they cast him out of the vineyard and killed him.

questions.question: What is the stone which the builders rejected according to Jesus in Luke 20:17?
options: Became the head of the corner
Was left unused
Broke into pieces
Was thrown away
questions.correctAnswer: Became the head of the corner
questions.explanation: Jesus said in Luke 20:17 that the stone rejected by the builders became the head of the corner.

questions.question: In Luke 20:22, what question did the spies ask Jesus?
options: Is it lawful to give tribute unto Caesar?
Who is the greatest in the kingdom?
When will the kingdom come?
Are the Pharisees righteous?
questions.correctAnswer: Is it lawful to give tribute unto Caesar?
questions.explanation: Luke 20:22 records the question about paying tribute to Caesar.

questions.question: What was Jesus' reply about giving unto Caesar and God in Luke 20:25?
options: Render unto Caesar the things which be Caesar's, and unto God the things which be God's.
Render all to God only.
Render all to Caesar only.
Refuse to pay tribute to anyone.
questions.correctAnswer: Render unto Caesar the things which be Caesar's, and unto God the things which be God's.
questions.explanation: Jesus answered in Luke 20:25 with the famous statement about rendering unto Caesar and unto God.

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 20:27, the Sadducees deny that there is any resurrection.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Luke 20:27 states that certain Sadducees deny the resurrection.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus said those worthy of the resurrection will marry and be given in marriage according to Luke 20:35.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 20:35 states that those worthy to obtain the resurrection neither marry nor are given in marriage.

questions.question: True or False: Luke 20:40 shows that after Jesus answered the Sadducees, they did not ask him any more questions.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In Luke 20:40, it says they dared not ask Jesus any question after his answer.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Luke 20:42: 'The LORD said unto my Lord, Sit thou on my ______,'
options: right hand
left hand
throne
mountain
questions.correctAnswer: right hand
questions.explanation: Luke 20:42 quotes Psalm where it says 'Sit thou on my right hand.'

medium.title: Luke Chapter 20 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Luke Chapter 20 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with understanding the source of Jesus' authority. Based on Luke 20, what biblical truth would you share about recognizing true spiritual authority?
options: True authority comes from God and is recognized by faith, not by human approval.
Authority is granted by popular opinion and public acceptance.
Authority depends on political power and wealth.
Authority is given only by religious leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: True authority comes from God and is recognized by faith, not by human approval.
questions.explanation: Jesus challenges the chief priests and scribes about John's baptism, showing that true authority is from heaven, not men (Luke 20:2-8). This teaches us to trust God's authority rather than human recognition (Luke 20:4-7).

questions.question: How does the parable of the vineyard in Luke 20 teach us about stewardship and accountability in God’s service?
options: Those entrusted by God must produce fruit and be faithful, or face consequences.
It is acceptable to neglect responsibilities if others do the work.
Only leaders are accountable to God for their actions.
God does not expect any return for His gifts.
questions.correctAnswer: Those entrusted by God must produce fruit and be faithful, or face consequences.
questions.explanation: The parable shows the vineyard owner entrusting servants and his son to the tenants, who abused and killed them, leading to judgment (Luke 20:9-16). This teaches accountability and faithful stewardship of God’s gifts.

questions.question: A believer is hesitant to confront sin in the church. What does Jesus' warning against the scribes in Luke 20 teach about integrity and humility in church leadership?
options: Leaders must serve with humility and avoid hypocrisy, or they will face severe judgment.
Leaders should seek honor and public recognition for their work.
It is acceptable to exploit others if it benefits the church.
Prayer and long robes guarantee spiritual authority.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must serve with humility and avoid hypocrisy, or they will face severe judgment.
questions.explanation: Jesus warns against scribes who love status and exploit widows but make long prayers for show, promising greater damnation (Luke 20:46-47). This highlights the importance of humility and integrity.

questions.question: How does Jesus' teaching on giving tribute to Caesar in Luke 20 guide believers on balancing civic responsibility and spiritual devotion?
options: Believers should fulfill civic duties while prioritizing their commitment to God.
Believers should reject all government authority to focus on God.
Spiritual devotion means ignoring earthly responsibilities.
Only religious leaders need to obey civil laws.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should fulfill civic duties while prioritizing their commitment to God.
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches to render to Caesar what belongs to him and to God what belongs to God (Luke 20:24-25), showing the balance between civic responsibility and devotion to God.

questions.question: A young couple is concerned about the meaning of marriage after death. How does Jesus' teaching in Luke 20 about the resurrection provide hope and understanding for Christian marriage?
options: In the resurrection, marriage as known on earth will not continue; believers will be like angels.
Marriage will continue in the same way after resurrection.
There is no resurrection, so marriage is only earthly.
Believers will remarry many times in heaven.
questions.correctAnswer: In the resurrection, marriage as known on earth will not continue; believers will be like angels.
questions.explanation: Jesus explains that those worthy of resurrection neither marry nor are given in marriage but are like angels, children of God (Luke 20:34-36), offering a new perspective on eternal life.

questions.question: How does Jesus’ response to the Sadducees’ question about resurrection in Luke 20 encourage believers facing doubts about eternal life?
options: God is the God of the living, affirming the reality of resurrection and eternal life.
There is no life after death, so focus only on this life.
Resurrection depends on human works alone.
Resurrection is a myth with no scriptural basis.
questions.correctAnswer: God is the God of the living, affirming the reality of resurrection and eternal life.
questions.explanation: Jesus points to Moses’ words about God being the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, who are alive, reinforcing resurrection (Luke 20:37-38). This comforts believers with assurance of life beyond death.

questions.question: A believer faces temptation to compromise faith for social acceptance. How does Jesus’ interaction with the chief priests and scribes in Luke 20 teach perseverance and courage?
options: Jesus boldly speaks truth despite opposition, showing the importance of standing firm in faith.
It is wiser to avoid conflict by agreeing with others.
Faith should be hidden to avoid persecution.
Compromise is necessary for peace.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus boldly speaks truth despite opposition, showing the importance of standing firm in faith.
questions.explanation: Jesus speaks parables and answers tricky questions without yielding to pressure, even when they seek to trap him (Luke 20:19-26). This models courage in faith.

questions.question: What does Jesus’ question about the stone the builders rejected in Luke 20 teach about humility and recognizing God's work?
options: God’s chosen foundation may be rejected by people but is ultimately supreme.
Only those with high social status are important to God.
God’s work is always accepted immediately by everyone.
Human opinion determines God’s plan.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s chosen foundation may be rejected by people but is ultimately supreme.
questions.explanation: Jesus cites the rejected stone becoming the cornerstone, teaching humility and trust in God’s plan despite rejection (Luke 20:17-18).

questions.question: How does the parable of the vineyard in Luke 20 guide believers in understanding God’s justice and mercy?
options: God is patient but will bring judgment on those who reject His messengers and Son.
God ignores injustice and wrongdoing indefinitely.
God’s mercy means no consequences for sin.
Judgment belongs only to human courts.
questions.correctAnswer: God is patient but will bring judgment on those who reject His messengers and Son.
questions.explanation: The vineyard owner sends servants and his son, who are mistreated and killed, leading to judgment on the tenants (Luke 20:10-16). This shows God’s patient mercy and ultimate justice.

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 20, Jesus accepted the authority of the chief priests and scribes who questioned Him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jesus does not directly answer their question about His authority but responds with a question about John’s baptism, avoiding their trap (Luke 20:2-8).

questions.question: True or False: Jesus taught that giving to government authorities and giving to God are mutually exclusive responsibilities.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches to render to Caesar what is Caesar’s and to God what is God’s, showing these responsibilities coexist (Luke 20:24-25).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jesus said, 'Beware of the ________, which desire to walk in long robes, and love greetings in the markets, and the highest seats in the synagogues.'
options: scribes
Pharisees
priests
elders
questions.correctAnswer: scribes
questions.explanation: Jesus warns specifically the scribes for their hypocritical behavior and desire for status (Luke 20:46).

questions.question: How does Jesus’ teaching about marriage and resurrection in Luke 20 encourage contentment and hope beyond earthly concerns?
options: Believers should focus on eternal life where earthly institutions like marriage do not apply.
Marriage is the ultimate goal of life.
Earthly relationships are permanent and unchanging.
Resurrection removes all hope for family reunion.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should focus on eternal life where earthly institutions like marriage do not apply.
questions.explanation: Jesus explains the resurrection transforms relationships; believers become like angels and children of God (Luke 20:34-36), encouraging hope beyond earthly ties.

questions.question: A believer is concerned about being judged for their actions. According to Luke 20, how does Jesus describe the consequences of rejecting God's chosen one?
options: Those who reject God’s chosen will be broken or crushed by the stone.
Rejecting God’s chosen has no consequences.
Only physical punishment is given for rejection.
God ignores rejection out of mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: Those who reject God’s chosen will be broken or crushed by the stone.
questions.explanation: Jesus says whoever falls on the rejected stone will be broken, and if it falls on someone, it will grind them to powder (Luke 20:18). This warns of severe spiritual consequences.

questions.question: What practical lesson about honesty and integrity can be learned from Jesus’ handling of the question about paying taxes in Luke 20?
options: Answer wisely and truthfully, recognizing legitimate authority without compromising faith.
Evade questions that challenge your beliefs.
Agree with any question to avoid conflict.
Ignore civic responsibilities to focus on religion.
questions.correctAnswer: Answer wisely and truthfully, recognizing legitimate authority without compromising faith.
questions.explanation: Jesus perceives their craftiness but answers with wisdom about rendering to Caesar and God, showing integrity and sound judgment (Luke 20:22-26).

hard.title: Luke Chapter 20 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Luke Chapter 20.

questions.question: In Luke 20, when Jesus is questioned about the authority by which He does His works, He replies by asking about the baptism of John. What is the significance of Jesus' question concerning John's baptism?
options: To trap the questioners into revealing their true allegiance
To avoid answering directly about His own authority
To affirm John's divine commission
To redirect the discussion towards the people's faith
questions.correctAnswer: To trap the questioners into revealing their true allegiance
questions.explanation: In Luke 20:3-6, Jesus cleverly asks if John's baptism was from heaven or from men, knowing that either answer would expose the questioners' true stance and put them in a dilemma.

questions.question: The parable of the vineyard in Luke 20 has strong Old Testament parallels. Which Old Testament passage is most directly echoed by this parable?
options: Isaiah 5:1-7
Psalm 23
Genesis 1
Exodus 20
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah 5:1-7
questions.explanation: The vineyard parable in Luke 20:9-16 echoes the Song of the Vineyard in Isaiah 5:1-7, where Israel is depicted as a vineyard that fails to produce good fruit, symbolizing unfaithfulness.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the 'stone the builders rejected' becoming the 'head of the corner' in Luke 20:17?
options: It symbolizes Jesus as the cornerstone of the new covenant
It refers to the foundation of the temple
It represents the destruction of Jerusalem
It denotes the authority of the chief priests
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes Jesus as the cornerstone of the new covenant
questions.explanation: Luke 20:17 cites Psalm 118:22, portraying Jesus as the rejected stone who becomes the essential cornerstone, symbolizing His role in establishing the new covenant.

questions.question: In Luke 20:25, Jesus says, 'Render therefore unto Caesar the things which be Caesar’s, and unto God the things which be God’s.' What does this statement reveal about the relationship between civic duty and spiritual obligation?
options: It distinguishes between earthly authority and divine authority
It implies all authority ultimately belongs to Caesar
It encourages people to prioritize government over God
It forbids paying taxes to secular rulers
questions.correctAnswer: It distinguishes between earthly authority and divine authority
questions.explanation: Jesus in Luke 20:25 acknowledges the legitimacy of earthly government while emphasizing ultimate allegiance to God, highlighting the dual responsibilities of believers.

questions.question: The Sadducees' question about resurrection in Luke 20:27-33 reflects their theological position. What was their core belief that this question challenges?
options: Denial of the resurrection of the dead
Belief in predestination
Acceptance of angels as messengers
Adherence to strict Mosaic Law
questions.correctAnswer: Denial of the resurrection of the dead
questions.explanation: Luke 20:27 introduces the Sadducees, who denied resurrection, and their question about marriage after resurrection aimed to challenge the concept of life after death.

questions.question: According to Jesus' answer in Luke 20:36, how are those who attain the resurrection described in relation to angels?
options: They are equal to the angels
They become angels
They surpass the angels
They are lower than angels
questions.correctAnswer: They are equal to the angels
questions.explanation: Jesus states in Luke 20:36 that the resurrected are equal to the angels, indicating a transformed, immortal state beyond earthly relations.

questions.question: In Luke 20:37-38, Jesus refers to Moses at the burning bush mentioning the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. What doctrinal point does Jesus make with this reference?
options: God is the God of the living, not the dead
Moses was the first to teach resurrection
The burning bush symbolizes God's holiness
God is only known through the patriarchs
questions.correctAnswer: God is the God of the living, not the dead
questions.explanation: Jesus uses Moses' words in Luke 20:37-38 to affirm that God is living and sustains the living, supporting the reality of resurrection and eternal life.

questions.question: What rhetorical device does Jesus use in Luke 20:41-44 when questioning how the Christ can be David's son if David calls him 'Lord' in the Psalms?
options: A paradox highlighting Jesus' divine and human nature
An allegory about kingship
A fable illustrating humility
A metaphor for spiritual blindness
questions.correctAnswer: A paradox highlighting Jesus' divine and human nature
questions.explanation: Jesus presents a paradox in Luke 20:41-44 that exposes the complexity of the Messiah's identity as both David’s son and Lord, pointing to His divine nature.

questions.question: How do the scribes react after Jesus' discourse on the resurrection and the Messiah's identity in Luke 20:39-40?
options: They agree with Him and refrain from further questioning
They immediately plan to arrest Him
They debate among themselves
They challenge Him with more questions
questions.correctAnswer: They agree with Him and refrain from further questioning
questions.explanation: According to Luke 20:39-40, some scribes acknowledge Jesus' wisdom and do not ask Him any more questions, showing a momentary respect.

questions.question: In Luke 20:46-47, Jesus warns His disciples about the scribes. What specific behaviors does He condemn?
options: Desiring honor, seeking the best seats, and exploiting widows
Teaching false doctrines and neglecting the poor
Engaging in hypocrisy and public prayer
Refusing to enter the temple and breaking the law
questions.correctAnswer: Desiring honor, seeking the best seats, and exploiting widows
questions.explanation: Jesus criticizes in Luke 20:46-47 the scribes for their pride, love of status, and exploitation of vulnerable widows, condemning their hypocrisy.

questions.question: What cultural practice relating to marriage does Jesus refer to in His response to the Sadducees in Luke 20:28-33?
options: Levirate marriage
Polygamy
Divorce and remarriage
Betrothal customs
questions.correctAnswer: Levirate marriage
questions.explanation: Luke 20:28-33 discusses the law of levirate marriage from Deuteronomy 25:5-6, where a brother marries the widow to raise offspring for the deceased brother.

questions.question: What historical and social tension underlies the question about paying tribute to Caesar in Luke 20:22-24?
options: The Jewish resistance to Roman taxation and occupation
The debate over temple tax payment
The question of Herodian loyalty
The conflict between Pharisees and Sadducees
questions.correctAnswer: The Jewish resistance to Roman taxation and occupation
questions.explanation: The question in Luke 20:22-24 reflects the political tension Jews felt under Roman rule, where paying tribute was controversial and seen as submission to foreign authority.

questions.question: True or False: In Luke 20:19, the chief priests and scribes feared the people because they perceived that Jesus' parable was spoken against them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Luke 20:19 states that the leaders wanted to seize Jesus but feared the people, recognizing that the parable was an indictment of themselves.

questions.question: True or False: In Luke 20:8, after the religious leaders refuse to answer about John's baptism, Jesus directly reveals the source of His authority.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 20:8 records Jesus saying He will not tell them by what authority He does these things, withholding direct revelation in response to their refusal to answer.

questions.question: What literary technique is employed in the structure of the parable in Luke 20:9-16, where servants and finally the son are sent and mistreated?
options: Progressive intensification to climax in rejection of the son
Allegorical inversion of roles
Chiasm highlighting the son’s importance
Parallelism between servants and husbandmen
questions.correctAnswer: Progressive intensification to climax in rejection of the son
questions.explanation: The parable in Luke 20:9-16 uses progressive intensification, escalating from beating servants to killing the son, emphasizing increasing rejection culminating in the son’s death.

theological.title: Luke Chapter 20 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Luke Chapter 20 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What question did the chief priests and scribes ask Jesus regarding His teaching authority?
options: By what authority doest thou these things?
Who do you say I am?
When will the kingdom come?
Why do you eat with sinners?
questions.correctAnswer: By what authority doest thou these things?
questions.explanation: The chief priests and scribes asked Jesus 'By what authority doest thou these things?' to challenge His teaching legitimacy, as stated in Luke 20:2. This question relates to divine authority, a key theme also seen in Matthew 21:23 and Mark 11:28.

questions.question: How did Jesus respond when asked about the baptism of John?
options: He asked whether it was from heaven or of men
He declared it was from heaven
He declared it was of men
He refused to answer
questions.correctAnswer: He asked whether it was from heaven or of men
questions.explanation: Jesus responded by asking them if John's baptism was from heaven or of men (Luke 20:4), exposing their dilemma and testing their honesty. This method highlights divine authority and prophetic endorsement, consistent with John the Baptist's role in Luke 1:17 and Malachi 3:1.

questions.question: In the parable of the vineyard, who does the beloved son represent?
options: Jesus Christ
John the Baptist
Moses
The Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: The beloved son in the parable symbolizes Jesus Christ who was sent by God and rejected by the leaders (Luke 20:13-15). This aligns with messianic themes found in Isaiah 53 and Psalm 2, showing the rejection and ultimate authority of Christ.

questions.question: What consequence did Jesus say would come upon the husbandmen who killed the son?
options: They will be destroyed and the vineyard given to others
They will be forgiven if they repent
They will suffer no consequence
They will be imprisoned
questions.correctAnswer: They will be destroyed and the vineyard given to others
questions.explanation: Jesus declared that the lord of the vineyard will destroy the husbandmen and give the vineyard to others (Luke 20:16), indicating judgment on Israel’s leaders and transfer of God's kingdom, a theme reflected in Isaiah 5:7 and Matthew 21:43.

questions.question: What is the significance of the stone which the builders rejected, according to Jesus?
options: It became the head of the corner
It was lost and forgotten
It was used for a foundation elsewhere
It was broken into pieces
questions.correctAnswer: It became the head of the corner
questions.explanation: Jesus referenced the rejected stone becoming the head of the corner (Luke 20:17), emphasizing His role as the cornerstone of salvation, as also prophesied in Psalm 118:22, Isaiah 28:16, and echoed in Acts 4:11.

questions.question: Why did the chief priests and scribes fear to seize Jesus immediately after the parable?
options: Because they feared the people
Because they doubted His identity
Because they lacked authority
Because Jesus escaped
questions.correctAnswer: Because they feared the people
questions.explanation: They feared the people's reaction as Jesus had spoken the parable against them (Luke 20:19), reflecting the tension between religious leaders and popular support for Jesus, consistent with John 11:47-48 and Matthew 21:46.

questions.question: What was Jesus' teaching regarding paying tribute to Caesar?
options: Render unto Caesar the things which be Caesar's, and unto God the things which be God's
Do not pay tribute to Caesar
Only pay tribute if it is voluntary
Give all to God and nothing to Caesar
questions.correctAnswer: Render unto Caesar the things which be Caesar's, and unto God the things which be God's
questions.explanation: Jesus taught a principle of dual responsibility to earthly and divine authority (Luke 20:25), a foundational teaching for Christian engagement with government, also supported by Romans 13:1-7 and Matthew 22:21.

questions.question: Who came to Jesus to challenge the doctrine of resurrection?
options: The Sadducees
The Pharisees
The chief priests
The scribes
questions.correctAnswer: The Sadducees
questions.explanation: The Sadducees, who denied the resurrection, questioned Jesus (Luke 20:27), representing a theological challenge to the doctrine of eternal life, which Jesus refuted by citing Moses and God as the God of the living (Luke 20:37-38), supported by Daniel 12:2 and Job 19:25-27.

questions.question: According to Jesus, what is true about those who attain the resurrection?
options: They neither marry nor are given in marriage
They continue earthly marriages
They die again
They live as common men
questions.correctAnswer: They neither marry nor are given in marriage
questions.explanation: Jesus explained that resurrected ones do not marry nor are given in marriage and are like angels (Luke 20:35-36), indicating a transformed existence beyond earthly institutions, a truth connected to John 5:28-29 and 1 Corinthians 15:42-44.

questions.question: What argument did Jesus use to prove the resurrection from the dead to the Sadducees?
options: He cited Moses at the burning bush calling God the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob
He performed a resurrection miracle before them
He quoted the Psalms about life after death
He referred to the prophets predicting resurrection
questions.correctAnswer: He cited Moses at the burning bush calling God the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob
questions.explanation: Jesus used the fact that God is called the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob in Exodus 3 (Luke 20:37-38), showing God is God of the living, not the dead, affirming resurrection, consistent with Hebrews 11 and Daniel 12:2.

questions.question: What question did Jesus ask about the Christ's relationship to David?
options: How is he then his son if David calls him Lord?
Who is the son of David?
Is the Christ greater than David?
When will the Son of David reign?
questions.correctAnswer: How is he then his son if David calls him Lord?
questions.explanation: Jesus challenged the understanding of the Messiah's lineage by asking how Christ can be David's son if David calls him Lord (Luke 20:44), highlighting the divine nature of Christ, consistent with Psalm 110:1 and Isaiah 9:6.

questions.question: What warning did Jesus give about the scribes in His audience?
options: Beware of the scribes who desire to walk in long robes and devour widows' houses
Beware of false prophets who deny Christ
Beware of Pharisees who neglect the law
Beware of tax collectors who cheat
questions.correctAnswer: Beware of the scribes who desire to walk in long robes and devour widows' houses
questions.explanation: Jesus warned about the scribes' hypocrisy and exploitation (Luke 20:46-47), emphasizing judgment for those who misuse religious authority, a theme also in Matthew 23:1-36 and Jeremiah 23:1-2.

questions.question: How did the people respond to Jesus' teaching about the stone the builders rejected?
options: They marveled and held their peace
They rejected Him outright
They questioned Him further
They tried to stone Him
questions.correctAnswer: They marveled and held their peace
questions.explanation: The people marveled at Jesus' wisdom and held their peace after His parable and teaching (Luke 20:26), showing amazement and respect, consistent with reactions in Luke 5:26 and John 7:46.

questions.question: What did Jesus say about the children of this world compared to the children of the resurrection?
options: The children of this world marry, but the children of the resurrection neither marry nor die
Both marry and die as usual
The children of this world live forever, the children of resurrection die again
The children of the resurrection marry many times
questions.correctAnswer: The children of this world marry, but the children of the resurrection neither marry nor die
questions.explanation: Jesus distinguished earthly life and eternal life by stating the children of this world marry, but those worthy of resurrection neither marry nor die anymore (Luke 20:34-36), highlighting eternal transformation, consistent with 1 Corinthians 15:51-54 and Revelation 21:4.

questions.question: Why did the religious leaders send spies to watch Jesus and try to trap His words?
options: To deliver Him to the governor's power and authority
To learn from His teachings
To invite Him to a feast
To protect Him from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: To deliver Him to the governor's power and authority
questions.explanation: The leaders sent spies pretending to be righteous men to trap Jesus' words and hand Him over to the governor (Luke 20:20), reflecting their intent to arrest Him, a plot also seen in Matthew 26:3-4 and John 11:57.
